label: accumulatio
description: The emphasis or summary of previously made points or inferences by excessive praise or accusation.

label: acutezza
description: Wit or wordplay used in rhetoric.

label: When a verb is placed at the beginning or the end of a sentence instead of in the middle. For example (from [_Rhetorica ad Herennium_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetorica_ad_Herennium)), "At the beginning, as follows: 'Fades physical beauty with disease or age.' At the end, as follows: 'Either with disease or age physical beauty fades.'"
description: https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/adjunction

label: aesthetics
description: The examination of symbolic expression to determine its rhetorical possibilities.

label: Giving a cause or a reason.
description: https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/aetiologia

label: affectus
description: A term used by the Italian Humanists of the Renaissance to describe the source of emotions or passions in the human mind.

label: ambigua
description: An ambiguous statement used in making puns.

label: anacoenosis
description: A speaker asks their audience or opponents for their opinion or answer to the point in question.

label: anacoluthon
description: An abrupt change of syntax within a sentence. (What I want is — like anybody cares.)

label: anadiplosis
description: Repeating the last word of one clause or phrase to begin the next.

label: anaphora
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek) [_ᾰ̓νᾰφορᾱ́_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E1%BC%80%CE%BD%CE%B1%CF%86%CE%BF%CF%81%CE%AC#Ancient_Greek) (ănăphorā́). A succession of sentences beginning with the same word or group of words.

label: anapodoton
description: Implying an omitted main clause by a subordinate clause. (If you only knew **...**)

label: anecdote
description: A brief narrative describing an interesting or amusing event.

label: animorum motus
description: The emotions.

label: antanaclasis
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek) [_ἀντανάκλασις_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E1%BC%80%CE%BD%CF%84%CE%B1%CE%BD%CE%AC%CE%BA%CE%BB%CE%B1%CF%83%CE%B9%CF%82#Ancient_Greek) (antanáklasis). A figure of speech involving a pun, consisting of the repeated use of the same word, each time with different meanings.

label: antiptosis
description: The substitution of one case for another.

label: antistrophe
description: In rhetoric, repeating the last word in successive phrases. For example (from [_Rhetorica ad Herennium_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetorica_ad_Herennium)), "'Since the time when from our state concord disappeared, liberty disappeared, good faith disappeared, friendship disappeared, the common weal disappeared.'" See also [epiphora](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/epiphora).

label: antithesis
description: The juxtaposition of contrasting ideas in balanced or parallel words, phrases, or grammatical structures; the second stage of the dialectic process.

label: apheresis
description: The removal or omission of the initial sound or syllable from a word. Examples in English are [_scarp_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/scarp#English) from earlier [_escarp_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/escarp#English), and colloquial [_splain_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/splain#English) from [_explain_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/explain#English).

label: apocope
description: The omission of the last letter or syllable of a word.

label: aporia
description: An attempt to discredit an opposing viewpoint by casting doubt on it.

label: aposiopesis
description: An abrupt stop in the middle of a sentence; used by a speaker to convey unwillingness or inability to complete a thought or statement.

label: apostrophe
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek) [_ἀποστροφή_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E1%BC%80%CF%80%CE%BF%CF%83%CF%84%CF%81%CE%BF%CF%86%CE%AE#Ancient_Greek) (apostrophḗ). A figure of speech consisting of a sudden turn in a text towards an exclamatory address to an imaginary person or a thing.

label: Arete
description: Virtue, excellence of character, qualities that would be inherent in a "natural leader," a component of _ethos_.

label: argument
description: Discourse characterized by reasons advanced to support conclusions.

label: argumentum ad baculum
description: Settling a question by appealing to force.

label: ars arengandi
description: Teaching of forensic speaking during the Medieval rhetorical era.

label: ars praedicandi
description: The art of preaching based on rhetorical ideas and introduced during the Medieval rhetorical era during an increasing intersection between rhetoric and religion.

label: asyndeton
description: The deliberate omission of [conjunctions](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/conjunction) that would normally be used.

label: audience
description: Real, imagined, invoked, or ignored, this is a concept that seems to be at the very center of the intersections of composing and rhetoric.

label: auxesis
description: To place words or phrases in a certain order to obtain a climactic effect, or to use a word or phrase which disproportionately amplifies something actually of a lesser nature.

label: axioms
description: The point where scientific reasoning starts. Principles that are not questioned.

label: Expression of hatred or contempt.
description: https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/bdelygma

label: Bomphiologia
description: Bombastic speech.

label: brevitas
description: Concise expression.

label: burden of proof
description: Theory of argument giving the obligation of proving a case to the challenging party.

label: canon
description: A term often used to discuss significant literary works in a specific field, used by [Cicero](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Cicero) to outline five significant parts of the rhetorical composition process.

label: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). The part of a letter which secures the goodwill of the recipient.
description: https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/captatio_benevoluntatiae

label: catachresis
description: The inexact use of a similar word in place of the proper one to create an unlikely metaphor. For example (from _Rhetorica ad Herennium_), "'The power of man is short'" or "'the long wisdom in the man.'"

label: charisma
description: An attribute that allows a speaker's words to become powerful.

label: circa rem
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). The circumstances _surrounding the act_ in one Roman topical system.

label: Climax
description: Climax occurs when words or sentences are used to increase weight by mounting degrees in parallel construction.

label: colon
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek) [_κῶλον_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CE%BA%E1%BF%B6%CE%BB%CE%BF%CE%BD#Ancient_Greek) (kôlon). A rhetorical figure consisting of a clause which is grammatically, but not logically, complete.

label: Common topics in eighteenth-century prefaces to English school grammars: an application of the ECEG database
concession
description: Acknowlededment of objections to a proposal.

label: Constraints
description: Referring to "persons, events, objects, and relations which are parts of the situation because they have the power to constrain decision and action needed to modify the exigence." Originally used by [Lloyd Bitzer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lloyd_Bitzer).

label: Consubstantiality
description: Substance commonality.

label: ConTeXt
description: The circumstances surrounding an issue that should be considered during its discussion.

label: CONTINGENCY
description: In rhetoric, it relates to the contextual circumstances that do not allow an issue to be settled with complete certainty.

label: Conversation Modeling on Reddit Using a Graph-Structured LSTM
Data
description: Initial evidence supporting a claim. ([Stephen Toulmin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_Toulmin))

label: deconstruction
description: Analyzing communication artifacts by scrutinizing their meanings and related assumptions, with the goal of determining the social and systemic connotations behind their structure.

label: Delectare
description: To delight; viewed by [Cicero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cicero) as one of the three goals of rhetoric.

label: Demos
description: The population of an ancient Greek state, considered a political entity; population; the common people.

label: dialectic
description: A rhetorical term that has been defined differently by Aristotle and Ramus, among others; generally, it means using verbal communication between people to discuss topics in order to come to an agreement about them.

label: diallage
description: Establishing a single point with the use of several arguments.

label: dispositio
description: In the classical theory of the production of speech ([pronuntiatio](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pronuntiatio)), dispositio refers to the stage of planning the structure and sequence of ideas. Often referred to as arrangement, the second of [Cicero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cicero)'s five rhetorical canons.

label: Dissoi Logoi
description: Contradictory arguments.

label: Docere
description: To teach; viewed by [Cicero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cicero) as one of the three goals of rhetoric.

label: dysphemism
description: A term with negative associations for something in reality fairly innocuous or inoffensive.

label: ecphonesis
description: A sentence consisting of a single word or short phrase ending with an [exclamation point](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/exclamation_point).

label: elocutio
description: In the classical theory of the production of a speech ([pronuntiatio](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pronuntiatio)), elocution refers to the stage of elaborating the wording of a text, using correct grammar and diction.

label: enthymeme
description: A type of argument that is grounded in assumed commonalities between a rhetor and the audience. For example, "(claim 1) Bob is a person. Therefore, (claim 3) Bob is mortal." The assumption (unstated claim 2) is that "People are mortal." A type of [syllogism](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/syllogism). Started by [Aristotle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aristotle).

label: In rhetoric, repeating the same word or phrase at the beginning of successive phrases for emphasis. For example (from [_Rhetorica ad Herennium_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetorica_ad_Herennium)), "'To you must go the credit for this, to you are thanks due, to you will this act of yours bring glory.'"
description: https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/epanaphora

label: epideictic
description: Ceremonial rhetoric, such as might be found in a funeral or victory speech.

label: epiphora
description: The repetition of a phrase or word at the end of several sentences or clauses. Also see anaphora.

label: epistemology
description: Philosophical study directed at understanding how people gain knowledge.

label: epistrophe
description: A succession of clauses, phrases or sentences that all end with the same word or group of words.

label: epithet
description: A term used as a descriptive and qualifying substitute for the name of a person, place or thing.

label: epizeuxis
description: Emphasizing an idea using one word repetition.

label: ethopoeia
description: The act of putting oneself into the character of another to convey that persons feelings and thoughts more vividly.

label: euphemism
description: An innocuous, inoffensive or circumlocutory term or phrase for something unpleasant or obscene.

label: evidence
description: In rhetoric, facts or testimony used to strengthen a claim.

label: exemplum
description: The citation of an example, either truthful or fictitious.

label: exigence
description: A rhetorical call to action; a situation that compels someone to speak out.

label: exordium
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin) [_exordium_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/exordium#Latin) (“[beginning](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/beginning)”). The introductory portion of an [oration](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/oration).

label: facetiae
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). Humor or wit.

label: faculty psychology
description: The mind contains faculties that include understanding, imagination, passion, and will. (18th century)

label: False consciousness
description: A distorted view of reality, people, and the world. ([Jurgen Habermas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jurgen_Habermas)).

label: Feminist rhetoric
description: Rhetorical theory concerned with feminism and its critique of social structures.

label: Field dependent transverse relaxation rate increase may be a specific measure of tissue iron stores
field-invariant
description: Standards for assessing arguments that are not determined by the particular field. ([Stephen Toulmin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_Toulmin))

label: figure
description: Unusual arrangement of language that tries to achieve unique meaning for ideas.

label: Forensic oratory and the jury trial in nineteenth-century America
Gens
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). An influential group of families.

label: graecismus
description: The use of Greek idiom.

label: hermeneutics
description: The theoretical underpinnings of interpreting texts, usually religious or literary.

label: heteroglossia
description: The many prolific languages of any culture.

label: homiologia
description: A tedious style or redundancy of style.

label: hyperbole
description: A figure of speech where emphasis is achieved through exaggeration, independently or through comparison. For example (from _Rhetorica ad Herennium_), "'His body was as white as snow, his face burned like fire.'"

label: hypophora
description: When a speaker asks aloud what their adversaries have to say for themselves or against the speaker, and then proceeds to answer the question. For example (from [_Rhetorica ad Herennium_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetorica_ad_Herennium)), "'When he reminded you of your old friendship, were you moved? No, you killed him nevertheless, and with even greater eagerness. And then when his children grovelled at your feet, were you moved to pity? No, in your extreme cruelty you even prevented their father's burial.'"

label: hypothesis
description: An educated guess.

label: hypozeuxis
description: A sentence in which every clause has its own subject and verb.

label: icon
description: Using imagery to create resemblance.

label: identification
description: Connecting with a larger group through a shared interpretation or understanding of a larger concept; [Kenneth Burke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_Burke) was one of the first people to use the term in this way.

label: ideology
description: A way of understanding one's external surroundings.

label: Induction
description: Rhetorical method for coming to general conclusions through specific examples.

label: insultatio
description: Abusing a person to their face by using irony and derisive language.

label: intersubjective agreements
description: agreements on the fair conduct of an argument among individuals participating in dialogue.

label: Invitational rhetoric
description: Rhetoric that is not intended to persuade. ([Sonja K. Foss](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonja_K._Foss), Cindy L. Griffin)

label: irony
description: A deliberate contrast between indirect and direct meaning to draw attention to the opposite.

label: isocolon
description: A string of phrases of corresponding structure and equal length.

label: issues of fact
description: Issues related to an act's occurrence.

label: jargon
description: Highly technical language used by specific group.

label: Jian Shi
description: From [Chinese](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_language) [_諫士_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/諫士)／[_谏士_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/谏士) (_jiànshì_). Traveling political advisors common in ancient China.

label: kairos
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek) [_καιρός_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CE%BA%CE%B1%CE%B9%CF%81%CF%8C%CF%82#Ancient_Greek) (kairós). Generally means "timing" or "the right circumstances."

label: koinoi topoi
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek). Common topics; in a rhetoric situation, useful arguments and strategies.

label: kolakeia
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek). Flattery; telling people what they want to hear while disregarding their best interests; employed by sophistic rhetoricians.

label: Lexis
description: Style.

label: literae humanae
description: Academic disciplines that are known as the liberal arts: languages, philosophy, history, literature, music, art and certain abstact sciences.

label: localism
description: A word, phrase, or custom particular to one's location.

label: loci communes
description: Types of arguments. [Quintilian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quintilian) trained orators to learn intellectual habits to access the arguments quickly.

label: locution
description: Refers to the utterance of a statement.

label: logical positivism
description: The effort to make scientific standards applicable for resolving all issues.

label: logical proof
description: Arguments used to persuade audience. Reasoned.

label: logology
description: Kenneth Burke. Study of the specific theological terms used. Not to find the truth or falseness of the statement, but why that particular word was chosen.

label: logos
description: Rhetorical appeals based on logic or reasoning.

label: magnanimity
description: Doing good to others, "its opposite is meanness of spirit" (from [Aristotle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aristotle)'s [_Rhetoric_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetoric_(Aristotle))).

label: major premise
description: Statement in a syllogism. Generalization.

label: material fallacy
description: False notion concerning the subject matter of an argument.

label: maxim
description: A saying drawn from life, which shows concisely either what happens or ought to happen in life, for example: 'Every beginning is difficult.' (from [_Rhetorica ad Herennium_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetorica_ad_Herennium))

label: meiosis
description: A figure of speech in which a word or phrase diminutively substitutes as a reference for something actually of a greater nature.

label: memory
description: Described by [Cicero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cicero) as the "firm mental grasp of matter and words;" the fourth of his five rhetorical canons.

label: meta-narratives
description: Universal theories positing to know all aspects of humanity.

label: metaphor
description: A figure of speech where a word that normally applies to one thing is used to designate another for the sake of creating a mental picture. For example (from [_Rhetorica ad Herennium_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetorica_ad_Herennium)), "'...he lightly breathed a favoring breath'".

label: Metron
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek). Measure.

label: Minor Premise
description: Statement in an argument.

label: modus inveniendi
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). Material used to understand the scriptures. ([Augustine of Hippo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Augustine_of_Hippo))

label: modus proferendi
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). expressing ideas found within the scriptures. ([Augustine of Hippo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Augustine_of_Hippo))

label: moral reasoning
description: Reasoning employed in rhetoric that determines a conclusion based on evidence. Used in issues of ethics, religion, economics, and politics.

label: Movere
description: To persuade; viewed by [Cicero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cicero) as one of the three goals of rhetoric.

label: necessary cause
description: Cause without which effect couldn't/wouldn't have occurred.

label: Neoplatonism
description: School of thought emanating from the works of [Plato](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plato) and [Aristotle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aristotle) in early B.C.E. Rome.

label: noema
description: Speech that is deliberately subtle or obscure.

label: non sequitur
description: A statement bearing no relationship to the preceding context.

label: oictos
description: To show pity or compassion.

label: onomatopoeia
description: Words that imitate the sounds, objects, or actions they refer to. (ex. "buzz", "hullabaloo," "bling")

label: optatio
description: A wish exclaimed.

label: oxymoron
description: A condensed paradox.

label: paradeigma
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek). Argument created by a list of examples that leads to a probable generalized idea.

label: paradox
description: A self-contradictory statement, which can only be true if it is false, and vice versa.

label: paralipsis
description: When a rhetor refuses to continue with their current discussion, or passes over the rest of the conversation, or admits that they do not know what else to say. For example, (from [_Rhetorica ad Herennium_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetorica_ad_Herennium)), "'Your boyhood, indeed, which you dedicated to intemperance of all kinds, I would discuss, if I thought this the right time. But at the present I advisedly leave that aside. This too I pass by, that the tribunes have reported you as irregular in military service.'"

label: parallel syntax
description: repetition of similar sentence structures.

label: particular audience
description: The actual audience the orator addresses. ([Chaïm Perelman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cha%C3%AFm_Perelman) and [Lucie Olbrechts-Tyteca](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucie_Olbrechts-Tyteca))

label: pathos
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek). The emotional appeal to an audience in an argument. One of [Aristotle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aristotle)'s three proofs.

label: personification
description: A figure of speech that gives human characteristics or inanimate objects, or represents an absent person as being present. For example (from [_Rhetorica ad Herennium_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetorica_ad_Herennium)), "'But if this invincible city should now give utterance to her voice, would she not speak as follows?'"

label: phallogocentrism
description: Examines the relationship between logos (reason) and the phallus (representative of male genitalia). Just as the phallus is implicitly and sometime explicitly assumed to be the only significant sexual organ, the masculine is the accepted as the central point of reference of validity and authority for a society.

label: phronesis
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek). practical wisdom; common sense.

label: physis
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek). the strong will rule over the weak.

label: pistis
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek). belief.

label: pleonasm
description: The use of more words than necessary to express an idea.

label: polyptoton
description: The repetition of a word or root in different cases or [inflections](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/inflection) within the same sentence.

label: polysyndeton
description: The repeated use of conjunctions within a sentence, particularly where they do not necessarily have to be used.

label: portrayl
description: Describing a person clearly enough for recognition. For example (from [_Rhetorica ad Herennium_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetorica_ad_Herennium)), "'I mean him, men of the jury, the ruddy, short, bent man, with white and rather curly hair, blue-grey eyes, and a huge scar on his chin, if perhaps you can recall him to memory.'"

label: positivism
description: Term created by [Auguste Comte](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Auguste_Comte) that posits that science, math, or logic can prove any reasonable claim.

label: pragmatism
description: Field of thought positing that knowledge was fluid and that traditionally "fixed" entities (like time) were largely contextual; believed that a free society with free individuals was a viable standard for living.

label: presence
description: Choosing to emphasize certain facts and ideas instead of others, leading the audience along that path. ([Chaïm Perelman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cha%C3%AFm_Perelman) and [Lucie Olbrechts-Tyteca](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucie_Olbrechts-Tyteca))

label: pronuntiato
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). The deliverary of an oration or an argument in a manner befitting the subject matter and style, while maintaining control of voice and body.

label: prudence
description: Judging practically.

label: psogos
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek). Blame.

label: psychagogos
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek). A poet.

label: Psyche
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek). The mind or soul.

label: public sphere
description: Place where individuals can engage in discussion without the political or state interests interfering.

label: purpose
description: What one is trying to do with their use of language.

label: quadrivium
description: The major subjects taught in medieval times: geometry, arithmetic, atronomy, and music.

label: quaestiones
description: Debatable points around which disputes are centered.

label: reasoning by contraries
description: Where the first statement of two opposite statements directly proves the second. For example (from [_Rhetorica ad Herennium_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetorica_ad_Herennium)), "'Or how should you expect a person whose arrogance has been insufferable in private life, to be agreeable and not forget himself when in power...?'"

label: Res
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). An argument's subtance.

label: rhetorical discourse
description: Discourse created within the boundary of the principles of rhetoric.

label: rhetorical opposition
description: [Protagoras](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protagoras)'s idea that there are two sides to everything.

label: rhetorical situation
description: A term made popular by [Lloyd Bitzer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lloyd_Bitzer); describes the scenario that contains a speech act, including the considerations (purpose, audience, author/speaker, constraints to name a few) that play a role in how the act is produced and perceived by its audience. The counterargument regarding Bitzer's situation-rhetoric relationship was made by [Richard E. Vatz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_E._Vatz) in "The Myth of the Rhetorical Situation." He argued for a salience-meaning (or now, agenda-framing-spin) model of persuasion, which emphasized rhetoric as a creative act with increased agent or persuader responsibility for the situation their rhetoric creates. He maintained this added to the importance of rhetorical study.

label: semantics
description: Philosophical study of language that deals with its connection to perceptions of reality.

label: semiotics
description: Branch of semantics concerning language and communication as a system of symbols.

label: Senatus
description: [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin) for "senate". The group of elders who governed Rome.

label: Shui
description: Formal persuasion in ancient China.

label: simile
description: A figure of speech that compares unlike things, implying a resemblance between them. For example (from [_Rhetorica ad Herennium_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetorica_ad_Herennium)), "'He entered the combat in body like the strongest bull, in impetuosity like the fiercest lion.'"

label: skepticism
description: Type of thought that questions whether universal truth exists and is attainable by humans.

label: soraismus
description: The ignorant or affected mingling of languages.

label: sprezzatura
description: The ability to appear that there is seemingly little effort used to attain success. The art of being able to show that one is able to deceive. ([Baldessare Castiglione](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baldessare_Castiglione))

label: stasis system
description: System of finding arguments by means of looking at ideas that are contradictory.

label: status quo
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). The generally accepted existing condition or state of affairs.

label: studia humanitas
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). Humanistic studies deemed indispensable in Renaissance-era education; rhetoric, poetics, ethics, politics.

label: syllepsis
description: A word modifying others in appropriate, though often incongruous ways. This is a similar concept to [zeugma](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/zeugma).

label: syllogism
description: A type of [valid](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/valid) argument that states if the first two claims are true, then the conclusion is true. For example, "(claim 1) People are mortal; (claim 2) Bob is a person. Therefore, (claim 3) Bob is mortal." Started by [Aristotle](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Aristotle).

label: syllogistic logic
description: See scientific reasoning.

label: symbol
description: A visual or metaphorical representation of an idea or concept.

label: symbolic inducement
description: Term coined by [Kenneth Burke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_Burke) to refer to rhetoric.

label: sympheron
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek). Path that is to one's advantage.

label: synchysis
description: Word order confusion within a sentence.

label: syncope
description: The omission of letters from the middle of a word, usually replaced by an [apostrophe](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/apostrophe).

label: synecdoche
description: A rhetorical device were one part of an object is used to represent the whole.

label: tapinosis
description: Language or an [epithet](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/epithet) that is debasing. This term is synonymous with [meiosis](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/meiosis).

label: taste
description: A learned admiration for things of beauty.

label: tautology
description: Redundant use of words, a [pleonasm](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pleonasm), an unnecessary and tedious repetition.

label: thesis
description: The major claim or premise made in an argument to be proved or dis-proved.

label: thesmos
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek). The law that comes from the authority of kings.

label: tone
description: The author's voice in an essay through use of figurative language or a style of enunciation in writing (also known as a [diction](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/diction)). The way the author expresses themself out loud or through a character.

label: topical systems
description: Methods for finding arguments.

label: topos
description: A line or specific style of argument.

label: topothesia
description: The description of an imaginary or non-existent place.

label: transgression
description: Reading a text and looking for the deeper meanings instead of the obvious ones.

label: translative issue
description: Dealing with procedure of an ensuing case.

label: trivium
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). Grammar, rhetoric, and logic taught in schools during the medieval period.

label: universal audience
description: An audience consisting of all humankind (most specifically of adult age and normal mental capacity).

label: utterance
description: Statement that could contain meaning about one's own person.

label: validity
description: Apprehension over the structure of an argument.

label: validity claim
description: Claiming to have made a correct statement.

label: Verba
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). The part of an argument that advances the subject matter.

label: vir bonus beni dicendi
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). The good man speaking well.

label: vita activa
description: A life lived in active involvement in the political arena.

label: Warrant
description: term used by [Stephen Toulmin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_Toulmin) to establish a link between data and a claim.

label: zeugma
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek) [_ζεῦγμα_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CE%B6%CE%B5%E1%BF%A6%CE%B3%CE%BC%CE%B1#Ancient_Greek) (zeûgma, “[yoking](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/yoke)”). A figure of speech in which one word applies to two others in different senses of that word, and in some cases only logically applies to one of the other two words. This is a similar concept to [syllepsis](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/syllepsis).

label: tricolon
description: The pattern of three phrases in parallel, found commonly in Western writing after [Cicero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cicero). For example, the kitten had white fur, blue eyes, and a pink tongue.

label: alloisis
description: The breaking down of a subject into its alternatives.

label: amplificatio
description: An all-purpose term for all the ways an argument can be expanded and enhanced.

label: amplification
description: The act and the means of extending thoughts or statements to increase rhetorical effect, to add importance, or to make the most of a thought or circumstance.

label: aphaeresis
description: The omission of a syllable from the beginning of a word.

label: apophasis/ apophesis
description: Pretending to deny something as a means of implicitly affirming it. Mentioning something by saying that you won't mention it.

label: appeals
description: Rhetorical devices used to enhance the plausibility of one's argument; [Aristotle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aristotle)'s appeals included [ethos](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ethos), [logos](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/logos), and [pathos](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pathos).

label: argumentum ad hominem
description: Using what you know about your opponent's character as a basis for your argument.

label: arrangement
description: See [dispositio](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/dispositio).

label: ars dictaminis
description: The art of writing letters, introduced and taught during the Medieval rhetorical era.

label: ars poetria
description: Medieval teaching of grammar and style through analysis of poetry.

label: artistic proofs
description: Rhetorically-produced methods for persuasion. For [Aristotle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aristotle), three possibilities would be [ethos](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ethos), [pathos](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pathos), and [logos](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/logos).

label: backing
description: Supporting an argument's merit.

label: barbarismus
description: Mispronunciation or unnatural word-usage.

label: bases
description: The issues at question in a judicial case.

label: bathos
description: An emotional appeal that inadvertently evokes laughter or ridicule.

label: belles lettres
description: Written works considered quality because they are pleasing to the senses.

label: belletristicmovement
description: Movement of rhetoric in the late 18th and early 19th centuries emphasizing stylistic considerations of rhetoric. It also expanded rhetoric into a study of literature and literary criticism and writing.

label: brachylogia
description: Brevity of diction.

label: claim
description: A primary point being made to support an argument. Or, the resulting conclusion to an argument. ([Stephen Toulmin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_Toulmin))

label: classicism
description: A revival in the interest of classical antiquity languages and texts.

label: common topics
description: Arguments and approaches useful in rhetorical settings; _koinoi topoi._

label: conclusio
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). A letter's conclusion.

label: confirmatio
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). The section of a judicial speech (in Roman rhetorical theory) that offers evidence supporting the claims given during the statement of facts.

label: confutatio
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). Counterargument in Roman rhetorical theory.

label: conversio
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). Varying sentence structure to discover its most agreeable form.

label: conversation model
description: The model, in critique of traditional rhetoric by [Sally Gearhart](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sally_Gearhart), that maintains the goal of rhetoric is to persuade others to accept your own personal view as correct.

label: cookery
description: [Plato](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plato) believed rhetoric was to truth as cookery was to medicine. Cookery disguises itself as medicine and appears to be more pleasing, when in actuality it has no real benefit.

label: critical theory
description: Systematically analyzing any means of communication for hidden assumptions and connotations.

label: deduction
description: Moving from an overall hypothesis to infer something specific about that hypothesis.

label: delivery
description: Fifth canon in [Cicero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cicero)'s list of rhetorical canons; traditionally linked to oral rhetoric, refers to how a speech is given (including tone of voice and nonverbal gestures, among others).

label: dictamen
description: The art of writing letters.

label: distribution
description: Dividing a whole subject into its various parts.

label: divisio
description: To divide into categories or classes.

label: dramatistic
description: A way to look at the nature of language stressing on language as an action. For example, it uses expressions such as 'thou shalt' and 'thou shalt not." ([Kenneth Burke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_Burke)).

label: enumeratio
description: Making a point more forcibly by listing detailed causes or effects; to enumerate: count off or list one by one.

label: ethos
description: A rhetorical appeal to an audience based on the speaker/writer's credibility.

label: fable
description: A short allegorical story.

label: facilitas
description: The improvising of effective oral or written language to suit any situation.

label: fictio
description: The attribution of rational traits to non-rational creatures.

label: field-dependent
description: Standards for assessing arguments that are specific to a certain field. ([Stephen Toulmin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_Toulmin))

label: forensic oratory
description: speaking in a courtroom.

label: forum
description: A way to complicate our notions of audience and to help writers consider important factors that affect planning and composing.

label: genera
description: Plural of [genus](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/genus). Classification by race, kind, or possession of similarities; discriptive of different types of oratory.

label: heuristics
description: Determining or applying the proper methods for investigation.

label: homoioteleuton
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek) [_ὁμοιοτέλευτον_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E1%BD%81%CE%BC%CE%BF%CE%B9%CE%BF%CF%84%CE%AD%CE%BB%CE%B5%CF%85%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%82#Ancient_Greek) (homoiotéleuton). A figure of speech where adjacent or parallel words have similar endings.

label: horismus
description: A brief and often antithetical definition.

label: hypsos
description: Great or worthy writing, sometimes called sublime. Longinus's theme in [_On the Sublime_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/On_the_Sublime).

label: ignoratio elenchi
description: A conclusion that is irrelevant.

label: imitatio
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). Imitation.

label: inartistic proofs
description: Discovered information stemming from the raw data of experience.

label: indefinite questions
description: Questions that are discussed without referring to anything specifically. ([Quintilian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quintilian))

label: indignatio
description: To arouse indignation in the audience.

label: ingenium
description: From [Latin](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Latin). The ability to understand similarities and relationships that is innate in all humans. ([Giambattista Vico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giambattista_Vico))

label: in re
description: From [Latin](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Latin). Arguments concerned with what actually happened.

label: institutio oratoria
description: Educational and rhetorical principles as described and prescribed in treatise by [Quintilian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quintilian).

label: interlacement
description: Combining the figures [antistrophe](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/antistrophe) and [epanaphora](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/epanaphora) for rhetorical style and emphasis. For example (from [_Rhetorica ad Herennium_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetorica_ad_Herennium)), "'Who are they who have often broken treaties? The Carthaginians. Who are they who have waged ware with severest cruelty? The Carthaginians.'"

label: invention
description: Described by [Cicero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cicero) as the process of determining "valid or seemingly valid arguments;" the first of his five rhetorical canons.

label: ioci
description: Jokes, see [Cicero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cicero)'s [_De Oratore_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_Oratore) and his theory of humor.

label: issues of definition
description: Things related to naming an act.

label: issues of quality
description: Issues related to the seriousness of an act.

label: judicial
description: Type of oratory used to attack or defend someone.

label: kategoria
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek). Accusation.

label: koinonia
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek). To consult with your opponent or judge.

label: latinitas
description: Stylistic feature involving the proper use of language.

label: logical fallacy
description: Misconceptions resulting from faulty reasoning.

label: metonymy
description: A figure of speech which substitutes one word or phrase for another with which it is closely associated. For example (from [_Rhetorica ad Herennium_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetorica_ad_Herennium)), "one should say 'wine' for 'Liber', 'wheat' for 'Ceres'."

label: motive
description: Something that plays a role in one's decision to act.

label: narratio
description: A presentation of essential facts in a judicial speech.

label: narration
description: Story telling, involving the elements of time, place, actor, action, cause and manner.

label: negatio
description: To negate or deny.

label: nomos
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek). a social custom or convention.

label: notaries
description: Secretaries trained in rhetoric for dealing with the agreements that were needed for commercial cities in Italy to function.

label: ominatio
description: A prophecy of evil.

label: opening
description: First part of discourse. Should gain audiences' attention.

label: orcos
description: An oath.

label: paronomasia
description: A play on words, often for humorous effect.

label: perfectus orator
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). A complete orator.

label: periphrasis
description: The substitution of many or several words where one would suffice; usually to avoid using that particular word.

label: peroratio
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). The last section of a judicial speech were the speaker is the strongest.

label: petitio
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). In a letter, an announcement, demand, or request.

label: pian
description: (Ancient China) the art of disputing.

label: plausibility
description: Rhetoric that is believable right away due to its association with something that the audience already knows or has experienced.

label: poetriae
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). Poetry as an art.

label: polis
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek). The city-state, especially the people in the city-state.

label: polyphonic
description: Having multiple voices.

label: position
description: The stance taken by a rhetor that they are attempting to prove through argumentation.

label: postmodernism
description: Related to rhetoric, a field of inquiry concerned with the ideological underpinnings of commonly held assumptions.

label: praedicandi
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). Preaching.

label: presumption
description: An idea is reasonable or acceptable only until it is sufficiently challenged.

label: protreptic
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek). The potential to persuade through language.

label: rebuttal
description: Conditions on the acceptability of a claim. ([Stephen Toulmin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_Toulmin))

label: rhetor
description: A person who is in the course of presenting or preparing rhetorical discourse.

label: rhetores
description: From [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek). Those who make a living by speaking persuasively.

label: rhetorical audience
description: Those who can be persuaded by rhetoric.

label: rhetorical theory
description: The organized presentation of the art or rhetoric, descriptions of the various functions of rhetoric, and clarifications of how rhetoric achieves its goals.

label: rhetoric of fiction
description: [Wayne Booth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wayne_Booth)'s idea that "the author's judgement is always present" in a narrative.

label: salon
description: Intellectual assembly in an aristocratic setting; primarily associated with France in the 1600s and 1700s.

label: salutatio
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). A written greeting.

label: sannio
description: From [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin). The fool. The role to avoid when using humor in a speech.

label: scholasticism
description: Rhetorical study of Christianity that was intellectually prominent in 11th-15th Century Western Europe, emphasizing rhetorical concepts by [Aristotle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aristotle) and a search for universal truth.

label: scientific method
description: A system of observing and analyzing data through induction; prominent school of thought since the 1600s whose proponents are often critical of rhetoric.

label: scientific reasoning
description: Moving from axioms to actual conclusions. Also, syllogistic logic.

label: scientism
description: Applying scientific assumptions to subjects that are not completely natural. ([Richard M. Weaver](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_M._Weaver))

label: scientistic
description: Way of looking at the nature of language as a way of naming or defining something. ex. "It is" or "It is not." ([Kenneth Burke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_Burke))

label: second sophistic
description: Rhetorical era in Rome that dealt primarily with rhetorical style through some of the Greek Sophists' concepts, while neglecting its political and social uses because of censorship.

label: sensus communis
description: a society's basic beliefs and values.

label: sententia
description: Applying a general truth to a situation by quoting a maxim or other wise saying as a conclusion or summary of that situation.

label: sign
description: Term from [semiotics](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/semiotics) that describes something that has meaning through its connection to something else, like words.

label: signifying
description: Term from [semiotics](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/semiotics) that describes the method through which meaning is created with arbitrary signs.

label: solecismus
description: Ignorantly misusing tenses, cases, and genders.

label: sophists
description: Considered the first professional teachers of oratory and rhetoric, in 4th century BC Ancient Greece.

label: starting points
description: The place between the speaker and audience where the argument can begin. ([Chaïm Perelman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cha%C3%AFm_Perelman) and [Lucie Olbrechts-Tyteca](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucie_Olbrechts-Tyteca))

label: tautologia
description: The same idea repeated in different words.

label: taxis
description: The distribution of a proper adjunct to every subject.

label: techne
description: [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek) for a true art.

label: terministic screens
description: Term coined by [Kenneth Burke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_Burke) to explain the way in which the world is viewed when taking languages and words into consideration.

label: theme
description: The basic principle pulled from the Bible in order to create a sermon.

label: topographia
description: The description of a place.

label: Toulmin model
description: A method of diagraming arguments created by Stephen Toulmin that identifies such components as [backing](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/backing), [claim](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/claim), [data](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/data), [qualifier](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/qualifier), [rebuttal](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/rebuttal), and warrant.

label: tropes
description: Figure of speech that uses a word aside from its literal meaning.

label: understatement
description: A form of irony, also called [litotes](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/litotes), in which something is represented as less than it really is, with the intent of drawing attention to and emphasizing the opposite meaning.

label: uomo universale
description: The universal man.

label: visual rhetoric
description: A theoretical framework describing how visual images communicate, as opposed to aural or verbal messages.

label: ways and means
description: One of the five main matters that [Aristotle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aristotle) claims political speakers make speeches on. It consists of the speaker's country's revenue and sources, as well as the expenditures of the country.

label: acrostic
description: A [poem](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/poem#Noun) or other [form](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/form#Noun) of [writing](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/writing#Noun) in which the [first](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/first#Adjective) [letter](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/letter#Noun), [syllable](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/syllable#Noun) or [word](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/word#Noun) of each [line](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/line#Noun), [paragraph](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/paragraph#Noun) or other [recurring](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/recurring#Adjective) [feature](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/feature#Noun) in the [text](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/text#Noun) [spells](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/spell#Verb) out a word or a [message](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/message#Noun).

label: accismus
description: A [feigned](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/feign#Verb) [refusal](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/refusal#Noun) of something [earnestly](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/earnestly#Adverb) [desired](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/desire#Verb).

label: alogism
description: An [illogical](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/illogical#Adjective) [statement](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/statement#Noun).

label: antilabe
description: A [technique](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/technique#Noun) in [drama](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/drama#Noun) in which a [single](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/single#Adjective) [verse](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/verse#Noun) line is [distributed](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/distribute#Verb) among two or [more](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/more#Adjective) [speakers](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/speaker#Noun).

label: apokoinu
description: A [construction](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/construction#Noun) in which a [word](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/word#Noun) or [phrase](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/phrase#Noun) serves as a [member](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/member#Noun) of [two](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/two#Numeral) [clauses](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/clause#Noun) or [sentences](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sentence#Noun).

label: aprosdoketon
description: A [figure](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/figure#Noun) in which an [unexpected](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/unexpected#Adjective) [word](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/word#Noun) or [phrase](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/phrase#Noun) [ends](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/end#Verb) a [sentence](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sentence#Noun).

label: captatio benevolentiae
description: A [rhetorical](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/rhetorical#Adjective) [technique](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/technique#Noun) aimed at [capturing](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/capture#Verb) the [goodwill](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/goodwill#Noun) of the [audience](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/audience#Noun).

label: chiffre
description: A [symbol](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/symbol#Noun) or [code](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/code#Noun) in [literature](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/literature#Noun) whose [meaning](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/meaning#Noun) is [obscure](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/obscure#Adjective).

label: chreia
description: A [short](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/short#Adjective) [essay](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/essay#Noun) or [composition](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/composition#Noun) that [expounds](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/expound#Verb) on a [well-known](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/well-known#Adjective) [saying](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/saying#Noun) or [action](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/action#Noun).

label: contamination
description: The [merging](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/merge#Verb) of [two](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/two#Numeral) or [more](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/more#Adjective) [words](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/word#Noun) into [one](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/one#Numeral).

label: concessio
description: A [rhetorical](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/rhetorical#Adjective) [figure](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/figure#Noun) in which a [point](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/point#Noun) is [conceded](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/concede#Verb) to the [opponent](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/opponent#Noun).

label: constructio ad sensum
description: A [grammatical](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/grammatical#Adjective) [agreement](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/agreement#Noun) of a [word](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/word#Noun) with the [meaning](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/meaning#Noun) rather than the [form](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/form#Noun).

label: diaphora
description: The [repetition](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/repetition#Noun) of a [word](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/word#Noun) in a [different](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/different#Adjective) [sense](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sense#Noun).

label: dicolon
description: A [sentence](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sentence#Noun) or [period](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/period#Noun) [consisting](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/consist#Verb) of [two](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/two#Numeral) [cola](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/colon#Noun).

label: eponomasie
description: The [substitution](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/substitution#Noun) of a [name](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/name#Noun) for a [quality](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/quality#Noun) or [vice versa](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/vice_versa#Adverb).

label: evidenz
description: A [description](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/description#Noun) so [vivid](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/vivid#Adjective) that the [hearer](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/hearer#Noun) [seems](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/seem#Verb) to [see](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/see#Verb) the [object](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/object#Noun).

label: exemplum
description: A [brief](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/brief#Adjective) [story](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/story#Noun) used to [make](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/make#Verb) a [point](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/point#Noun) or [illustrate](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/illustrate#Verb) a [moral](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/moral#Adjective).

label: floskel
description: A [superficial](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/superficial#Adjective) or [hackneyed](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/hackneyed#Adjective) [phrase](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/phrase#Noun).

label: hypophora
description: A [figure](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/figure#Noun) in which a [speaker](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/speaker#Noun) [raises](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/raise#Verb) a [question](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/question#Noun) and then [immediately](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/immediately#Adverb) [answers](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/answer#Verb) it.

label: inkonzinnität
description: The [deliberate](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/deliberate#Adjective) [avoidance](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/avoidance#Noun) of [parallel](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/parallel#Adjective) [structures](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/structure#Noun).

label: invocation
description: An [address](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/address#Noun) to a [deity](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/deity#Noun) or [muse](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/muse#Noun).

label: cacophony
description: A [harsh](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/harsh#Adjective), [discordant](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/discordant#Adjective) [mixture](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mixture#Noun) of [sounds](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sound#Noun).

label: konzinnität
description: [Symmetry](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/symmetry#Noun) or [proportion](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/proportion#Noun) in [style](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/style#Noun).

label: malapropism
description: The [mistaken](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mistaken#Adjective) [use](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/use#Noun) of a [word](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/word#Noun) in [place](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/place#Noun) of a [similar-sounding](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/similar-sounding#Adjective) one.

label: montage
description: The [process](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/process#Noun) of [editing](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/edit#Verb) [separate](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/separate#Adjective) [pieces](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/piece#Noun) into a [single](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/single#Adjective) [whole](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/whole#Noun).

label: paradigma
description: A [typical](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/typical#Adjective) [example](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/example#Noun) or [pattern](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pattern#Noun) of something.

label: paraprosdokian
description: A [figure](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/figure#Noun) of [speech](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/speech#Noun) in which the [latter](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/latter#Adjective) [part](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/part#Noun) of a [sentence](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sentence#Noun) or [phrase](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/phrase#Noun) is [unexpected](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/unexpected#Adjective).

label: pluralis auctoris
description: The [use](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/use#Noun) of the [first-person](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/first-person#Adjective) [plural](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/plural#Noun) by an [author](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/author#Noun) [referring](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/refer#Verb) to [themselves](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/themselves#Pronoun).

label: pluralis majestatis
description: The [use](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/use#Noun) of a [plural](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/plural#Noun) [pronoun](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pronoun#Noun) by a [monarch](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/monarch#Noun) or [other](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/other#Adjective) [high](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/high#Adjective) [official](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/official#Noun) [referring](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/refer#Verb) to [themselves](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/themselves#Pronoun).

label: pluralis modestiae
description: The [use](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/use#Noun) of the [plural](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/plural#Noun) [referring](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/refer#Verb) to [oneself](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/oneself#Pronoun) as a [token](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/token#Noun) of [modesty](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/modesty#Noun).

label: pointe
description: A [witty](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/witty#Adjective) or [ingenious](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ingenious#Adjective) [thought](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/thought#Noun) or [remark](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/remark#Noun).

label: prokatalepsis
description: A [figure](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/figure#Noun) in which a [speaker](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/speaker#Noun) [anticipates](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/anticipate#Verb) and [responds](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/respond#Verb) to an [opponent's](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/opponent#Noun) [argument](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/argument#Noun).

label: sermocinatio
description: A [figure](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/figure#Noun) in which a [speaker](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/speaker#Noun) [represents](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/represent#Verb) [another](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/another#Adjective) [person](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/person#Noun) as [speaking](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/speak#Verb).

label: stichomythie
description: A [technique](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/technique#Noun) in [verse](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/verse#Noun) [drama](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/drama#Noun) in which [sequences](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sequence#Noun) of [single](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/single#Adjective) [alternating](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/alternate#Verb) [lines](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/line#Noun) are [given](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/give#Verb) to [each](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/each#Adjective) [speaker](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/speaker#Noun).

label: aporia
description: A [state](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/state#Noun) of [puzzlement](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/puzzlement#Noun) or [doubt](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/doubt#Noun).

label: argumentum ad baculum
description: An [argument](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/argument#Noun) [resorting](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/resort#Verb) to the [threat](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/threat#Noun) of [force](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/force#Noun).

label: axiom
description: A [self-evident](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/self-evident#Adjective) [truth](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/truth#Noun).

label: ignoratio elenchi
description: The [formal](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/formal#Adjective) [fallacy](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/fallacy#Noun) of [ignoring](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ignore#Verb) the [issue](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/issue#Noun).

label: kairos
description: The [opportune](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/opportune#Adjective) [time](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/time#Noun) and [place](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/place#Noun) for [stating](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/state#Verb) or [doing](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/do#Verb) something.

label: spin
description: A [form](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/form#Noun) of [propaganda](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/propaganda#Noun) [achieved](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/achieve#Verb) through [providing](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/provide#Verb) an [interpretation](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/interpretation#Noun) of an [event](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/event#Noun).

label: lipogram
description: A [text](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/text#Noun) in which a [certain](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/certain#Adjective) [letter](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/letter#Noun) is [omitted](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/omit#Verb).

label: euphony
description: A [pleasing](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pleasing#Adjective) [sound](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sound#Noun).

label: glossolalia
description: The [phenomenon](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/phenomenon#Noun) of [speaking](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/speak#Verb) in [tongues](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/tongue#Noun).

label: grotesque
description: A [style](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/style#Noun) of [decorative](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/decorative#Adjective) [art](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/art#Noun) [characterized](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/characterize#Verb) by [fanciful](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/fanciful#Adjective) or [fantastic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/fantastic#Adjective) [human](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/human#Adjective) and [animal](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/animal#Adjective) [forms](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/form#Noun).

label: Adynaton
description: Vergleich mit Unmöglichem

label: Allegorie
description: Verbildlichung, ausgeführte Metapher, im Allgemeinen ein Gleichnis; häufig wird hierbei eine abstrakte Idee durch etwas Gegenständliches ausgedrückt (siehe auch: Symbol )

label: Alliteration
description: Zwei oder mehrere unmittelbar aufeinander folgende Wörter besitzen den gleichen Anfangslaut

label: Anastrophe
description: Vertauschung zweier zusammengehörender Wörter (auch: Inversion )

label: Anthropomorphismus
description: Übertragung menschlicher Eigenschaften auf unbelebte Gegenstände (siehe auch: Verdinglichung )

label: Antizipation
description: eine Vorausschau bzw. einen Zeitsprung in die Zukunft oder durch den Text geweckte Lesererwartungen (siehe auch: Vorausdeutung )

label: Antiklimax
description: Abfallende Steigerung, Gegenteil zur Klimax

label: Antiphrasis
description: Es soll das Gegenteil des eigentlich Gesagten ausgedrückt werden; kann sich auf ein einzelnes Wort, einen Satz oder eine Passage beziehen; eine der häufigsten Formen der Ironie

label: Antitheton
description: Gegenüberstellung zweier entgegengesetzter Gedanken (kein Widerspruch) (siehe auch: Antithese )

label: Antonomasie
description: Sonderfall der Synekdoche , Eigenname als Gattungsbegriff (oder umgekehrt)

label: Assonanz
description: Vokalischer Halbreim

label: Buchstabendreher
description: Meist Vertauschung der anlautenden Konsonanten, seltener der Vokale, zweier zusammengehöriger Wörter, so dass sich ein neuer, meist alberner Sinn oder Klang ergibt; Sonderfall: Schüttelreim , engl. Spoonerismus , franz. „Contrepèterie“ (siehe auch: Paronomasie , Polysemie , Wortspiel , Neologismus )

label: Chiasmus
description: Symmetrische Überkreuzstellung von syntaktisch oder semantisch entsprechenden Satzteilen (siehe auch: Epanodos , Parallelismus )

label: Dreier-Figur
description: Siehe: Trikolon

label: Ellipse
description: Auslassung von Satzteilen (siehe auch: Brachylogie , Zeugma )

label: Emphase
description: Nachdrückliche Hervorhebung eines Wortes zur Gefühlsverstärkung

label: Enjambement
description: Fortführung eines Satzes über das Vers-/Zeilenende hinaus

label: Exclamatio
description: Ausruf

label: Figura etymologica
description: Verwendung von zwei oder mehr sprachgeschichtlich verwandten Wörtern in einem Kolon

label: Geminatio
description: Sonderfall der Repetitio ; Verdoppelung (siehe auch: Anadiplose , Anapher , Epipher , Kyklos , Symploke )

label: Hendiadyoin
description: Syntaktische Beiordnung eines semantisch untergeordneten Begriffs (oft falsch verstanden: Zwei Wörter mit gleicher oder sehr ähnlicher Bedeutung werden zur Verstärkung der Gesamtaussage verwendet [siehe: Tautologie ])

label: Hypallage
description: Zuordnung eines Attributs zum falschen Substantiv

label: Hyperbaton
description: Einschub durch Umstellung; zwei Wörter, die syntaktisch (und inhaltlich) zusammengehören, stehen weit voneinander

label: Hysteron-Proteron
description: Nachholtechnik; das logisch/zeitlich Nachfolgende wird an den Anfang gestellt (Sonderfall: Anachronismus )

label: Inversion
description: Umkehrung der normalen Wortstellung im Satz zur Hervorhebung des Umgestellten (auch Anastrophe )

label: Kyklos
description: Sonderfall der Repetitio , Wiederholung des Satz-/Versanfangs am Ende (Schema: x … x ) (siehe auch: Anadiplose , Anapher , Epipher , Geminatio , Symploke )

label: Litotes
description: Hervorhebung eines Begriffs durch Untertreibung, Abschwächung oder doppelte Verneinung

label: Parallelismus
description: Paralleler Aufbau von (Teil-)Sätzen

label: Paraphrase
description: Erklärende Umschreibung (als Zusatz) (siehe auch: Periphrase )

label: Parataxe
description: Nebeneinanderstellen gleichwertiger Hauptsätze bzw. beigeordneter Nebensätze (Gegenteil zur Hypotaxe , siehe auch: Satzreihe )

label: Parenthese
description: Einschub von Wörtern oder Satzteilen im Satz

label: Repetitio
description: Wiederholung eines Wortes/Satzteils (siehe auch: Anadiplose , Anapher , Epanalepse , Epipher , Geminatio , Kyklos , Polyptoton , Symploke )

label: Rhetorische Frage
description: Frage, auf die keine Antwort erwartet wird (Scheinfrage)

label: Sarkasmus
description: Beißender, bitterer und/oder verletzender Spott und Hohn; oft unter Verwendung von Ironie (z. B. als Reaktion auf einen Angriff) (siehe auch: Zynismus )

label: Tetrakolon
description: Viergliedriger Ausdruck, bei dem alle vier Teile semantisch gleich aufgebaut sind und zueinander parallel und/oder chiastisch stehen (siehe auch: Dikolon , Trikolon )

label: Zynismus
description: (Als rhetorisches Stilmittel:) Boshaft verletzende, oft ironische Äußerung als Demonstration der Überlegenheit, unter Missachtung, Umdeutung oder Ad-absurdum-Führung allgemein verbreiteter/anerkannter Werte (siehe auch: Sarkasmus )

label: Dispoziție
description: etapa de planificare a structurii și secvenței ideilor; adesea denumită aranjament, a doua dintre cele cinci canoane retorice ale lui Cicero.

label: Graphème
description: Lettres de l'alphabet, lettres étrangères, lettres inconnues

label: Phonème
description: Accents, sons, syllabes, voyelles et consonnes, groupes vocaliques et consonantiques, pieds versifiés

label: Morphème
description: Mots, groupes de mots, particules et conjonctions, codes typographiques, ponctuation, étymologie

label: Sème
description: Connotation, polysémie, lexique, vocable, antonymie, synonymie, champs sémantiques

label: tétramètres
description: « Quatre bœufs attelés , d'un pas tranquille et lent, Promenaient dans Paris le monarque indolent » — Boileau , Le Lutrin

label: hémistiche
description: « J'aime le son du c or , le soir, au fond des bois, Soit qu'il chante les pl eur s de la biche aux abois, Ou l'adieu du chass eur que l'écho faible accueille, Et que le vent du n or d p or te de feuille en feuille. » — Vigny , Poèmes antiques et modernes , Le Cor , I

label: annomination
description: [Stylistique] synonyme de paronomase (latin adnominatio , traduction du grec paronomase )

label: antanaclase
description: Répétition, dans une même phrase, d'un mot employé chaque fois avec une acception différente

label: épiphore
description: [Poétique] répétition d'un mot ou d'un vers en fin de strophe

label: épizeuxe
description: Répétition contiguë d'un même terme sans coordination

label: polyptote
description: Répétition de plusieurs termes de même racine, ou encore un même verbe sous différentes formes. Le mot subit des variations morpho-syntaxiques

label: cliché
description: Répétition d'une image ou d'une tournure usées par un emploi fréquent et populaire et hautement prévisible et souvent littéraire ou artistique

label: parrhésie
description: Figure d'adjonction qui consiste à dire ce qu'on a de plus intime en cherchant ses mots ; proche de la licence et du "franc parler"

label: périssologie
description: Faute d’écriture par redondance, qui consiste à l’ajout d’un ou de plusieurs détails inutiles qui n’apportent rien à la compréhension d’une idée ni à l’expression de cette idée, sinon pour l’alourdir ; proche du pléonasme

label: poncif
description: Répétition d'une expression banale et conventionnelle ; proche du lieu commun ou du cliché

label: redondance
description: [Stylistique] répétition monotone de la même idée en plusieurs formulations différentes au sein d'une même phrase. Voir pléonasme

label: épenthèse
description: addition interne d'un phonème ou d'une syllabe que l'étymologie ne justifie pas ou pour en faciliter l'articulation (sens phonétique) ou obtenir un effet particulier (sens stylistique) la paragoge est un ajout à la fin du mot et la prothèse , au début

label: antépiphore
description: Répétition d'un même groupe de mots (ou d'un même vers) au début et à la fin d'un paragraphe (ou d'une strophe) produisant un effet de clôture ; proche de l' épiphore , de l' épanadiplose et de l' anaphore

label: auxèse
description: Accumulation de termes ou d'expressions d'une grande intensité ou hyperboliques, à gradation positive

label: mot-valise
description: Elusion d'au moins deux autres mots existant dans la langue ; proche du néologisme et de l' haplologie

label: néologisme
description: Création et utilisation d'un mot ou d'une expression qu'on vient de former à partir d'éléments déjà existants dans la langue elle-même ; proche du mot-valise

label: tapinose
description: Accumulation de termes ou d'expressions d'une grande intensité ou hyperboliques à gradation négative

label: chleuasme
description: Consiste à en rajouter sur soi-même en se dépréciant pour mieux se dédouaner, ou pour recevoir des éloges ; figure ironique

label: truisme
description: Expression évidente et n'apportant aucune information

label: lipogramme
description: consiste à ne pas utiliser sciemment une lettre donnée

label: élision
description: amuïssement de la voyelle finale d’un mot devant un autre mot à initiale vocalique

label: parataxe
description: juxtaposition des phrases, sans mot de liaison explicitant le rapport syntaxique de subordination ou de coordination qui les unit ; contraire de l' hypotaxe

label: amphibologie
description: ambiguïté grammaticale et syntaxique qui donne lieu à diverses interprétations d'une même phrase

label: antiphrase
description: emploi, dans une situation caractérisée, des mots contraires à sa pensée pour mieux l'exprimer. Cette figure qui sous-tend l'ironie est proche de la litote , de l' antithèse et de l' euphémisme

label: aphorisme
description: formule brève qui résume l'essentiel d'une pensée

label: apophtegme
description: parole mémorable ayant valeur de maxime

label: aposiopèse
description: consiste à interrompre une phrase ou un vers sans achever sa pensée

label: brachylogie
description: emploi d'une expression elliptique, ou plus courte qu'une autre aboutissant à un discours bref, variante de l' ellipse (rhétorique)

label: gnomisme
description: figure d’effacement (d’une démonstration logique notamment) sous forme de sentence, de proverbes ou de maximes, généralement pour exprimer une vérité morale, une leçon, une règle de vie, un conseil ; proche de l’ enthymème

label: parabole
description: consistant en une courte histoire qui utilise les événements quotidiens pour illustrer une morale ou une doctrine, proche de l' allégorie et de la maxime

label: antimétabole
description: chiasme qui consiste à reprendre les mots d'une phrase dans une autre mais en en modifiant l'ordre de présentation, proche de l' anadiplose et de l' épanadiplose

label: énallage
description: changement brusque de temps, de mode, de nombre ou de genre, afin de dramatiser une situation.

label: hypozeuxe
description: [stylistique] maintien, par des mots associés, du parallélisme entre les termes d'une énumération pour l'équilibre ou la cadence de la phrase

label: parallélisme
description: succession de deux segments de phrase qui ont la même construction syntaxique en un rapport de symétrie et de répétition, proche de l' anaphore et du chiasme . L' hypozeuxe en est une variante

label: tmèse (rhétorique)
description: variante de l' hyperbate qui consiste en la division d'un mot composé, dont les parties se retrouvent séparées par un ou plusieurs mots

label: antiparastase
description: figure de réarrangement consistant à s'appuyer sur un argument faible pour le retourner en sa faveur

label: métalepse
description: [Stylistique] figure de style qui consiste à prendre la cause pour la conséquence. [Narrative] Intrusion ou implication du narrateur extérieur dans son propre discours.

label: prolepse
description: [syntaxe] expression anticipée, dans le COD de la principale, du sujet de la subordonnée comme dans « Regarde cette auto, comme elle est belle » [stylistique] emploi d'un terme (souvent un adjectif), qui représente par concision un état antérieur ou postérieur au moment de l'énoncé [rhétorique] réfutation anticipée d'une objection possible. [narratologie] la prolepse - ou anticipation - est une figure de style par laquelle sont mentionnés des faits qui se produiront bien plus tard

label: anantapodoton
description: substitution de la structure syntaxique du premier membre d'une phrase alternative (en « ou bien… ou bien »), par une formule synthétique, souvent exclamative

label: solécisme
description: Faute de syntaxe (construction incorrecte) permettant d'aboutir à un langage populaire proche du barbarisme

label: verbigération
description: synonymes d' amphigouri . Flux de paroles inutiles n'apportant aucune nouvelle information, proche du phébus et du galimatias

label: chosification
description: Transformation ou transposition d'une abstraction en un objet concret, visant à appréhender un concept, comme une chose concrète, variante de l' allégorie

label: circonlocution
description: forme d' ironie qui consiste en l'allongement de l’expression visant à masquer son embarras ou à dissimuler une idée

label: digression
description: Introduction de propos étranger au sujet général d'un discours, d'un débat, d'un écrit

label: éthopée
description: Description des mœurs d'un personnage, variante de l' hypotypose

label: prosopographie
description: Description animée et comme vivante d'un personnage ou d'un groupe de personnages, variante de l' hypotypose

label: question rhétorique
description: fausse question destinée à garder la parole ou à émouvoir

label: sermocination
description: utilisation d'un personnage imaginaire, historique ou abstrait pour évoquer ses assertions ; variante de la prosopopée

label: symbole
description: énoncé narratif ou descriptif polysémique, susceptible d'une double interprétation sur le plan de la réalité et sur le plan des idées ; lien indirect qui unit une image et une idée ou un concept reposant sur une métonymie ou une métaphore et à l'origine de l' allégorie
